title-group.subtitle: Spectroscopic Techniques in Obstetrics and Gynecology Applications

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, USA
2Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Istanbul University School of Medicine, Istanbul, Turkey
3Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Massachusetts General Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, USA

author-notes.corresp: John Yeh, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Massachusetts General Hospital, 55 Fruit Street, Boston, MA 02114 , USA. Email: jyeh@partners.org

abstract.p: In recent years, advances in spectroscopic techniques led to an increase in their medical applications. In medical sciences, emphasis is increasingly placed on instrumental techniques and accurate, quantitative measurements. It is especially apparent in diagnosis, where imaging techniques and laboratory results have became invaluable and compulsory. Breakthroughs in biochemistry made it possible to characterize physiological processes and living organisms at the molecular level. This led to a proliferation of new methods such as DNA tests and the use of biomarkers in daily clinical practice. Characterization of molecular structure and determination of the composition of a mixture are the fields of analytical chemistry and analytical biochemistry.

body.p: Different spectroscopic techniques have been utilized in characterizing soft matter. Techniques such as magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS), mass spectroscopy, infrared spectroscopy, and Raman spectroscopy have all been proven powerful techniques in characterizing and understanding soft matter.

In the field of obstetrics and gynecology, emphasis is increasingly placed on instrumental techniques and accurate, quantitative and most importantly noninvasive measurements. Such measurements not only can yield information on the state of health of a given person but also may shed light on the development of disease and on physiological processes. During the last decade, variety of spectrometric techniques has been used successfully in the field of obstetrics and gynecology, especially in gynecologic cancer and research for early detection of gynecologic cancers and find out useful biomarkers.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Sir Isaac Newton's simple experiments marked the beginning of the science of spectroscopy, but it was properly born in 1802, when the British scientist William Wollaston discovered the existence of dark lines in the solar spectrum. In 1859, when German physicist Gustav Kirchhoff was able to successfully purify substances and conclusively show that each pure substance produces a unique light spectrum, analytical spectroscopy was born.1

From the discovery of unique atomic spectra developed modern spectroscopy in the 20th century. Spectroscopy involves the study of light to determine the chemical composition of substances and the physical properties of molecules, ions, and atoms. Light is a type of electromagnetic radiation. Electromagnetic waves radiate from electrically charged particles that are set in motion when an electric field couples with a magnetic field. The waves act like a stream of particles without mass termed photons. The energy of these photons is inversely related to the wavelength of the radiation. Components of the electromagnetic spectrum relevant to diagnostic spectroscopy for tissue include the ultraviolet (UV) A range (315-400 nm), the visible light range (400-700 nm), and the near infrared (NIR) range (700-900 nm). When light strikes the tissue, it can be absorbed with or without reemission or scattered by surface or subsurface interactions.2

Throughout the years, different spectroscopic techniques have been utilized in characterizing soft tissues in the field of obstetrics and gynecology. In this review, we discuss the usage of spectroscopic techniques in the fields of gynecologic oncology, infertility, obstetrics, and general gynecology and attempt to provide a brief look at possible future applications.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A review of the literature was conducted to evaluate the use of spectroscopic techniques as a clinical tool in the field of obstetrics and gynecology. This review also examined how clinicians are using spectroscopy for searching biomarkers and screening and diagnosis of diseases in the field of obstetrics and gynecology.

Studies and clinical case reports published within the previous 15 years were reviewed. Sources were identified via the US National Library of Medicine’s MEDLINE and PubMed databases using the keywords obstetrics, maternal fetal medicine, gynecology, infertility, gynecologic oncology, and spectroscopy.

sec.title: Fourier-Transform Infrared Spectroscopy
sec.p: Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIRS) is an absorption spectroscopy technique, including microwave, infrared, and UV spectroscopy, and measures the wavelengths of light that a substance absorbs to give information about its structure (see Table 1). This is a powerful tool for determining biochemical composition within a biological system and for monitoring the physical state of the biochemical compounds.3 Generally, FTIRS is able to analyze carbohydrates, amino acids, lipids, and fatty acids as well as proteins and polysaccharides simultaneously.4

caption.p: Methods and Properties of Spectroscopic Techniques.

list-item.p: Useful for testing unknown biological material 3

To use selection of embryonic stem cell

To predict preeclampsia and prevent from its effect

Analysis of scattered light from laser illuminated sample promoting vibrational excitation or relaxation along a symmetrical vibrational mode4

To use embryo selection instead of grading system
To use selection of embryonic stem cell

Measure concentration of chemical compound in endometrium & ovarian cyst fluid between benign and malign tumors26

To diagnose the gynecologic disease and cancer at early stage

fn.p: Abbreviations: IUGR, intrauterine growth retardation; DM, diabetes mellitus.

sec.p: The FTIRS is a well-established vibrational spectroscopic method that is extensively used to analyze molecular species in biological samples. The principle of FTIRS is based on molecular vibrational modes, like stretching and bending of chemical bonds in a molecule. Upon exposure to light (electromagnetic radiation), molecules increase in vibrational energy due to light absorbance and vibrate at characteristic frequencies depending on their chemical structure. The FTIRS may also be used as a quantitative method for determining concentrations of components within a sample (Table 2).4

list-item.p: Absorption technique (microwave, infrared and ultraviolet).
Measures the wavelengths of the light that a substance absorbs to give information about this structure.
FTIR is a high- throughput capable of measuring 1000s of spectra in a single day
Molecular vibrational modes (like stretching and bending of chemical bonds in a molecule)

Vibrational method → exposure light (electromagnetic radiation) → molecule increase energy due to the light absorbs and vibrate → measure vibration at characteristics (2500 and 25000 nm) → then be correlated to single bonds or function group of molecules
Sensitivity and selectivity are not as high as MS
Water absorbs IR very strongly making aqueous samples challenging

tr.td: Used in metabolomics by analyzing functional groups in molecular species

list-item.p: Absorption spectroscopy
Effective scattering parameters
Light that is back scattering
Same advantage of FTIR(is a high-throughput capable of measuring 1000s of spectra in a single day)
Differs from FTIR (predominantly measure overtone) and combination vibrational frequencies of functional groups (R-H, N-H, C-H, S-H)
Low NIR, absorbance is advantageous in many respects as many different types of materials may be analyzed without sample preparation
Instrumental cost and complexity are reduced
Multivariate algorithms are required for analysis of NIR spectra to extract chemically relevant information
Multivariate models built from NIR data tend to be more accurate for quantitative purposes then those derived from IR
The overtone and combination bands tend to be very broad and overlapping relative to the sharp, well-separated fundamental features found in the IR region.

tr.td: Analyzing ionization of metabolites of molecular species

list-item.p: Separation of ionic fragments according to their mass to change ratio and their detection of these separations
Counterpart to MRS

As only medium-high abundant chemicals can be detected by MRS, MS-based metabolomics provides a more analytically sensitive alternative with the ability to detect metabolites at the micromolar concentration level, typical of physiological concentrations
Also capable of quantitative analyses
Metabolite and structure identification through molecular weight is determined
Time consuming (sometimes takes hours just for 1 tissue sample evaluation because of defining the difference between molecular ionic fragments)
Vibrational technique 400-4000 cm−1.
Wavelengths that a structure reflects upon excitation by vibration
A laser is utilized to promote a vibrational excitation or relaxation along a molecular vibrational mode
By analyzing the scattered light from the laser illuminated sample the amount of light absorbed at a number of vibrational frequencies can be deduced

Differs FTIR and NIR spectra tend to contain information from asymmetric vibrational mode while Raman (R), preferentially reflect symmetric vibrational mode. Thus, IR and R are often considered to be perfectly complementary techniques when combined. → They provide information on all of the fundamental vibrational modes of molecules
Advantage→ water provides only weak Raman signals which can disturb results
To achieve more accurate results, it has to be combined with FTIRS

tr.td: Analyzing properties of atomic nuclei of molecular species

list-item.p: Provides a multivariate analysis approach by non-destructively examining intact tissue and biological fluids.
Fundamental physicochemical mechanisms is completely different from other analytical techniques.
Provides a different scientific perspective.
Intrinsically quantitative.
Time costly à ranging from less than a minute to a few hours per measurement.
Limitations à cost, reproducibility and practicality (large equipment, complex operation scheme).
Emission spectroscopy technique which measures the amount of light of a certain wavelength that a substance reflects
Limited usage because of specialization only in a few medical applications for the time being.

fn.p: Abbreviations: FTIRS, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy; NIRS, near-infrared diffuse reflectance spectroscopy; MRS, magnetic resonance spectroscopy; MS, mass spectroscopy.

sec.p: The FTIRS can detect changes in cellular composition and changes in the molecular interactions in the cell that may reflect the onset of disease. The spectral changes are the results of changes in the configuration of molecules of functional groups in a cell or tissue, which are the key factors that differentiate abnormal from normal.4 This FTIRS property was used in a research study. This device is used to detect spectral differences between the tissues under different components (proteins, lipids, and nucleic acid) and focuses on their spectral changes. The FTIR spectroscopic analysis of normal (n = 5) human placental tissues compared with tissue from individuals with pregnancy-complicated diseases like intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR; n = 5) and diabetes mellitus (DM; n = 5). Tissues were collected from patients who had vaginal delivery within 24 hours. The tissues were divided into 3 parts: the upper one-third portion (P1; nearest part to amnion fluid), the middle portion (P2), and the lower one-third portion (P3). Sample tissues were put into physiological saline and preserved at 4°C. Their IR spectra were measured within 24 hours. Tissues were washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). Afterward the samples were cut off (2-mm diameter pieces) and used for the FTIR measurement. The rest of the tissue was fixed in formalin and stained with hematoxylin and eosin ([H&E] cell staining) and periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) reaction (glycan staining) for histological investigation. Placental tissues were also investigated histochemically. The differences in spectra especially of P2 FTIR spectra among P1, P2, and P3 in normal placentas were observed. The findings indicated pathological and biochemical changes in placental tissues in IUGR and DM via the usage FTIRS. They correlated their finding with histochemical staining of placenta. This method was helpful in early diagnosis and identification of IUGR and DM. Despite the small sample size, this study showed that FTIR is potentially useful when it can be applied to clinical study.5

Also this is a new technology for cervical cancer screening. Instead of detecting the morphological changes as used in Pap smear test, this technique detects, at the molecular level, structural changes in functional groups through the changes in the infrared absorption spectrum. The FTIRS is inexpensive and less time consuming, and it examines cells in their natural state (no fixation and staining). Moreover, it is a computer-operated system; the screening of a large number of cervical samples is feasible by a continuously automated process. When the infrared light is passed through a cervical cell sample, a molecule absorbs infrared radiation of the appropriate frequency, which excites it from one vibrational or rotational level to another. A graph of energy absorbed versus frequency is the absorption spectrum of the sample. The FTIR spectra can be interpreted as normal and abnormal results. For cervix cancer, Sindhuphak et al utilized FTIRS. Sample, which was taken from cervix with a spatula, was placed in 10 mL of normal saline and kept at −20°C for a month before preparation. The saline specimens were centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 10 minUTES and the cell pellets were transferred to microcentrifuge, centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 10 minutes to provide a small pellet of cells for FTIR analysis, and then stored at −80°C until the spectral analysis was carried out. Results were compared to the histologic diagnosis (gold standard). The FTIRS yielded high sensitivity (96.3%) and specificity (96.4%) and offered good false-negative rates (3.7%) and negative predictive values (97.6%).6

The FTIRS may be useful in predicting precancerous lesions because the cancerous processes induce cellular changes at the molecular level that are reflected on the FTIR spectra. Cervical biopsy specimens were obtained from the outpatient department. Chang et al utilized FTIRS in comparing cervical precancerous tissue samples of 22 patients with the pathological examination of colposcopic biopsies. All the samples were frozen at −20°C and stored until use. Two successive 8 µm thick sections were taken from each tissue and cut by microtome at −20°C. One was placed on the platinum-covered microscopic slide and used for spectroscopic studies. The other section was placed on a glass slide, dipped in formalin, and stained with H&E using the standard procedure. The slide was then examined by a pathologist. Considerable differences in the spectra were observed between normal and premalignant epithelial tissue. The ratios of normal and precancerous tissues were 1.40 ± 0.91 and 0.29 ± 0.19, respectively. The results established that color mapping method of FTIRS could assist early diagnosis of cervical precancerous tissue, on the basis that the changes in the spectra match pathological changes in the cervical tissue. Therefore, FTIRS can be an alternative screening technique for screening where Pap smear screenings are insufficient even though it can be time consuming.7

sec.title: Raman Spectroscopy
sec.p: Raman is a scattering spectroscopy technique is similar to emission spectroscopy but detects and analyzes all of the wavelengths that a substance reflects upon excitation by vibration (see Table 1). In a Raman experiment, a laser is utilized to promote a vibrational excitation (Stokes) or relaxation (anti-Stokes) along a molecular vibrational mode. By analyzing the scattered light from the laser-illuminated sample, the amount of light absorbed at a number of vibrational frequencies can be deduced. The resulting spectrum contains vibrational information about specimen, which is unique to the specimen.4

In infertility the limitations of morphologic evaluation of embryos have led many investigators to pursue adjunctive technologies for the assessment of the reproductive potential of a given embryo. The complete array of small-molecule metabolites that are found within a biological system constitutes the metabolome and reflects the functional phenotype. Metabolomics is the systematic study of this dynamic inventory of metabolites as small molecular biomarkers representing the functional phenotype in a biological system (see Table 2).

Raman spectroscopy is potentially one of the most valuable techniques.4,22 It was utilized to select the embryo on 69 spent media samples (samples were frozen at −20°C and thawed right prior to spectroscopic evaluation) from 30 patients. Raman spectral measurements were made. A large variation was observed in signals obtained from different samples consistent with variations expected from embryo metabolism. Signals obtained by Raman spectropscopy were mean centered by subtracting the mean at each wave number, and the mean values were calculated for each of the groups. They used this method to find out the component of embryonic culture media, which contains metabolites. Seli et al found that embryos that result in pregnancy may be different in their metabolomic profile (pyruvate, lactate) from embryos that do not and that the difference may be detected by the rapid, noninvasive evaluation of the embryonic culture media using targeted spectroscopic analysis and bioinformatics. They showed as well that Raman spectroscopy correlates with pregnancy outcome.22 It predicted viability of individual embryos with a sensitivity of 86% and a specificity of 76.5%. In another study Scott et al also used Raman spectroscopy to profile metabolomic detail of embryonic culture media in bigger group. Raman-compatible 1 mm diameter quartz sample cells were filled with 15 µL of sample media for the spectral measurements. Spectra were recorded from 50 to 3450 cm−1 at room temperature (25°C ± 1°C). Integration time was 5 minutes per sample. Both an empty sample cell and a water spectrum were repeated with every 4 samples to monitor dark signal and laser drift in the system. Their findings suggested that in vitro cultured embryos that have a high reproductive potential alter their environment differently compared with embryos that do not result in a pregnancy and that the difference is detectable by using spectroscopy.23

sec.title: Near-Infrared Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy
sec.p: This is an absorption spectroscopy technique as well. The NIRS is based on elastic scattering and absorption phenomena (see Table 1). Light that is backscattered from the surface can be analyzed to glean information about subcellular structures such as nuclei. This reflectance is mirror like in nature. Diffuse reflectance refers to the combination of light refracted by cells and other substances below the surface in addition to surface reflection. The reflectance characteristics of a given tissue are a function of its morphology and architecture, including angiogenesis.2

The NIRS is a noninvasive and convenient method of monitoring tissue oxygenation of a number of intact organs.8 The NIRS was used for evaluation of placental function during fetal growth restriction. Participants included 282 delivered neonates that were appropriate for gestational age (AGA) and small for gestational age (SGA). The NIRS targeted placenta at around 20 weeks, 30 weeks, and after 36 weeks of gestation and calculated tissue oxygen indexes (TOIs). High value of TOIs reflected low maternal fetal oxygen change. This study found that NIRS provided information about TOI, which are higher in SGA than AGA group. If the placental oxygenation conditions could be noninvasively measured during pregnancy; it would provide valuable information about oxygenation of the fetus, association between growth restriction, hypoxia, and so on.12

The NIRS is also used to characterize optical properties of thick tissues in vivo. Optical properties can be quantitatively defined in terms of absorption and reduced scattering coefficients; these parameters are sensitive to the tissue concentration of light-absorbing molecules ( oxyhemoglobin [O2Hb], deoxyhemoglobin [HHb], H2O, and lipids) and light-scattering structures (such as cell components and fibrous material in the extracellular matrix which contains collagen, elastin, etc). Banos et al9 came up with a model to predict preterm labor by using NIRS properties, which detect optical properties of cervical ripening. They studied drug-induced cervical ripening in 10 volunteers for abortion using topical misoprostol. They manufactured a probe, which was specifically designed for measurements of the human uterine cervix. The vaginal probe was slightly bent allowing good visualization during placement on the cervix. Eight multimode silica fibers (400 mm diameter, 3MFT 400 EMT, Thorlabs, Inc, Newton, New Jersey) were coupled to the laser source to transmit the light to the tip of the probe without any need of sample preparation. They measured light absorbing molecules and light scattering structure. They found increase in water content and decrease in collagen amount during cervical ripening.10 The NIRS is able to give this information by its properties, which are discussed above.

According to the NIRS properties, it was utilized to predict preterm labor. In another study, Hornung et al examined 13 patients’ cervixes various times during their pregnancy by vaginal probe.10 Differences in cervixes tissue between the secfond and the third trimester were statistically significant. Banos et al and Hornung et al9,10 indicated that NIRS is a promising diagnostic tool for measuring cervical O2Hb, HHb, total hemoglobin (tHb), and water. In combination with the scattering properties, NIRS provided useful information on the status of the cervix and its ripening. Therefore, before the start of cervical ripening, NIRS may detect the beginning of preterm labor and this can become an interesting alternative for physicians. On the other hand, there should be more studies that are randomized and have a wider sample size.

A different approach was to differentiate cervical softening levels in different phases of menstrual cycle.11 The NIRS was used to examine in vivo the optical properties of human cervical tissues in various menstrual phases. The study included 20 premenopausal (menstrual period [n = 4], follicular phase [n = 7], luteal phase [n = 9]), and 9 postmenopausal women who were scheduled for hysterectomy. Cervical softening was measured by vaginal probe, which is a part of NIRS before operation. The vaginal probe of the FD-NIRS instrument was inserted into the vagina and placed on the vaginal portion of the uterine cervix with gentle pressure, ensuring good probe-to-cervix contact but without altering perfusion. Measurements were taken once on each quadrant of the cervix. This study demonstrated that withdrawal of sex hormones during menstrual bleeding is associated with a significant decrease in HHb and scattering power, with stable values of O2Hb, tHb, oxygen saturation (StO2), and H2O compared with the values during the follicular, luteal, or postmenopausal phases of the menstrual cycle. Cervical softening during menstrual bleeding seemed to be different from cervical softening for labor.

In another study on infertility by Seli et al, spent embryonic culture media were collected after single embryo transfer on day 3 (n = 304) or day 2 (n = 181) and analyzed by NIRS. Spectrometer-compatible 3 mm path length sample cells were filled with 7 µL of sample culture media and placed in the sample chamber (maintained at 21.0°C ± 0.1°C) for spectral measurements. Sample analysis time was approximately 1 minute. The measurement was repeated with the control medium to account for any variation in culturing conditions between embryos. Metabolomic profiling of embryonic culture media using NIRS is independent of morphology and correlates with reproductive potential of embryos.13 Vergouw et al used this new tool NIRS on an extended number of embryonic culture media samples and found similar results.14 The NIR spectral analysis produced unique metabolomic profiles that correlated to an embryo’s reproductive potential. The result between positive and negative pregnancy outcomes was statistically significant (P < .03).

The NIRS analysis (spectral results) and also profiling (level of pyruvate, lactate, etc) of spent embryonic culture media may be able to help distinguish viable embryos from nonviable embryos for reproduction.

sec.title: Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy
sec.p: Magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) is a noninvasive technique that can be used to determine chemical structure of molecules and, more recently, to study tissue biochemistry24 (see Table 1). The MRS is based on magnetic properties of atomic nuclei; this technique provides a multivariate analysis approach by nondestructively examining intact tissue and biological fluids. The MRS is intrinsically rich in information, offering structural and quantitative information simultaneously, with metabolite identification capabilities of even the most complex of mixtures, without the need of separation or sample preparation.

The MRS is seen more frequently in a major problem in obstetrics, namely eclampsia and preeclampsia. The MRS was utilized to determine the spectral differences between edema and ischemia in the brain of 10 women with eclampsia.25 Several metabolites (lactic acid, N-acetyl-l-aspartic acid [NAA]), which provide information about chemical change in the brain, were measured without sample preparation via the usage of MRS. Measurement is possible since each metabolite has a different spectrum. In patients with acute cerebral ischemia, in vivo MRS showed an increase in lactate less than 24 hours after the onset of stroke, even when no conventional MR imaging abnormalities were detectable. The marked decline in NAA in these patients correlated well which probably resulted from gross neuronal damage. Results by Sengar et al25 suggested that in vivo MRS may help to differentiate cerebral edema from ischemia in patients with eclampsia and thus may help to determine the prognosis for these patients. With the aid of this approach, aggressive or expectant management can be chosen by the caregivers and relatives.

The MRS allows noninvasive in vivo measurement of various chemicals, which can provide information regarding the metabolism, cellular composition, and pathophysiology of different lesions.26 As endometrial cancer is the most common cancer of the genital tract and it represents 10% of all cancers diagnosed in women,26 MRS has been widely utilized to measure the concentrations of chemical metabolites in various tissues; choline, creatine, lactate, and lipid were found as important metabolites in the spectra. Celik et al proposed to show the feasibility of in vivo MRS for studying endometrial pathology and to image the differences in selected metabolites (ie, choline, creatine, lactate, and lipid) between different endometrial pathologies in 12 patients who had untreated uterine bleeding.26 Endometrial thickness was measured in the sagittal plane from one basal layer to the other by transvaginal ultrasonography. Immediately after MRS, endometrial biopsies were collected from all participants by dilatation and curettage. Metabolite levels were compared with the histological diagnosis obtained from the endometrial biopsy in women undergoing curettage. After evaluation of samples by MRS, they found different concentrations of metabolites, which were useful to distinguish the disease. After the patients were evaluated with MRS, their endometrial biopsy samples were examined by a pathologist. Findings were varying. They indicated that a diffuse, probably global, metabolic abnormality occurs in association with endometrial carcinoma. The most pronounced change was an increase in lipid signal. In tumor of uterine cervix, an elevated lipid peak, demonstrated by MRS, has been suggested to be a possible indicator of malignancy. Lipid signal was obtained from all patients with endometrial carcinoma but none of the normal patients. This study had a weakness because of the small sample size and lack of a control group. But the findings are novel because the approach does not involve an invasive procedure.26

Spectroscopy technologies are not only tools to diagnose diseases but also new alternatives for finding potential biomarkers for different diseases. Therefore they can play a vital role in research. One such study tried to find a biomarker to detect ovarian cancer in its early stages. The MRS was used to study cyst fluid samples, which were randomly selected from cyst fluid bank (malign [n = 3], borderline [n = 3], and benign [n = 6], and they demonstrated the presence of a resonance with in vivo MRS in the cyst fluid of a patient with an ovarian tumor. Cyst fluid samples were measured in 3 different ways: (1) in their native state (not deproteinized or pH standardized); (2) after deproteinization over a 10-kDa cutoff filter (Sartorius, 3000g for 70 minutes; before use, the filter was washed twice by centrifugation with water to remove glycerol); (3) as in ref,2 but additionally pH adjusted to 2.50 ± 0.10. For analysis, 50 mL of D2O and 20 mL of TSP were added to 700 mL of the sample. Increased NAA in the cyst fluid sample, which was detected by MRS seemed to be a biomarker for benign serous cysts. These results are in line with the findings of the previous study by Boss et al. On the other hand, the spectroscopic resonance was significantly more prominent in the cyst fluid of mucinous tumors than in the cyst fluid of other histological subtypes.25,27,28

The MRS also was utilized to compare metabolic composition of cyst fluid between benign and malignant ovarian tumors. Cysts fluid was obtained from 40 patients (pathological diagnosis after evaluation of cyst: 28 benign and 12 malignant) by aspiration before cystectomy. Within 30 to 60 minutes after cooled transport, all samples were centrifuged at 3000g for 5 minutes for cell separation and immediately stored at −35°C. Sample processing involved deproteinization, freeze drying, and redissolution in D2O adjusted to pH 2.5 ± 0.10 and was performed. There were 36 metabolites with high intersample variation. Significant differences in concentration were found for several metabolites. Higher and lower concentrations in benign fluids were compared to normal serum values. They concluded that MRS of ovarian cyst fluid could give valuable information about the presence of low-molecular-weight metabolites and about cyst metabolism. This was a pilot study, in which in vitro MRS performed, the first of its kind on ovarian cyst fluid samples, described significant differences in metabolic composition of cyst fluid from benign and malignant ovarian cysts.28

The MRS can give an overview of low-molecular-weight metabolites that are present in tissues and fluid samples. Its application may be useful especially for diagnosis in differentiation of benign versus malignant tissues. The MRS may also be useful for looking at disorders of metabolism and certain inflammatory and ischemic diseases.

sec.title: Mass Spectroscopy
sec.p: Mass spectrometers (MSs) operate by ionization of metabolites, separation of ionic fragments according to their mass-to-charge ratio, and then detection of these separated ions (see Table 1). The MS-based experiments provide a more analytically sensitive alternative with the ability to detect metabolites at the micromolar concentration level, typical of physiological concentrations. The MS is also capable of quantitative analyses and the metabolite and structure identification through molecular weight determination (see Table 2).4

The MS technology has been evaluated as a new means to track biological responses to therapy. The measurement of a protein profile at different stages of disease progression or before and after treatment, combined with protein microarray technologies, constitutes a new paradigm for detecting disease and monitoring disease response to therapy. Ultimately, proteomics and genomics may become integrated into management of patient with cancer through the design and tracking of individualized therapy.15

The MS can be useful to understand the pathophysiology of metabolic mechanism of human biology and also helpful to identify the biomarkers of disease. The MS has been used to identify protein biomarkers and a discriminatory proteomic profile biomarker (PPB) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) that distinguishes severe preeclampsia (n = 7) from both mild preeclampsia (n = 8) and normotensive control group (n = 7). A 1 to 2 mL sample of CSF was collected and a 0.5-mL aliquot of CSF was sent immediately for cytologic analysis. Manual cell counts (cells/mm3) were performed on unspun CSF samples by a single technician who was blinded to the patient’s clinical condition. The remaining sample was stored at −80°C prior to analysis. Serial dilutions of pooled samples were screened onto a range of ProteinChip array surfaces. Results established a PPB score based on the presence or absence of discriminatory protein peaks in individual CSF tracing. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) was also utilized to identify the biomarker composing the PPB score. The presence of nanomolar amounts of free hemoglobin in the CSF of women with severe preeclampsia (6.6 mg/mL but not mild: 0 mg/mL or control: 0mg/ml) was a novel finding of this research group. Discriminatory protein peaks comprising the PPB score were free chains of hemoglobin of the protein peaks.16

A comparison of sera of patients with endometrial cancer to those of healthy females using MS yielded a number of potential biomarkers upon evaluations with 3 data mining tools. The MS detected 13 putative markers. The diagnostic pattern combined with 13 putative markers made it possible to differentiate patients with endometrial cancer from healthy participants with specificity of 100% and sensitivity of 92.5% in sera of patient.14

The methodology in the study by Petricoin et al on ovarian cancer aimed to recognize signature protein patterns.18 Thousands of peaks were analyzed by an interactive searching artificial intelligence algorithm. Using the results of training set (50 patients with ovarian cancer and 50 patients with normal sera), mass spectra were evaluated from 50 women with confirmed ovarian cancer and 66 controls from unaffected women or those with nonmalignant disorders. They suggested that serum proteomic pattern might reflect the underlying pathological state of an organ. Also their hypothesis was that proteomic pattern shows diagnostic sensitivity with 100% and specificity with 95% for ovarian cancer.18 Even though Nandi et al have used MS for discovery and identification of serum carrier protein–bound peptide biomarker candidates in ovarian cancer samples,15 they have not produced any evidence to support their contentions regarding cancer-specific spectra or metabolites. Also their findings remain unduplicated by them or others.

The MS technology has been evaluated as a new means to track biological responses to therapy as well. The measurement of a protein profile at different stages of disease progression or before and after treatment, combined with protein microarray technologies, constitutes a new paradigm for detecting disease and monitoring disease response to therapy. The MS was used to find new biomarkers for detection and monitoring ovarian cancer. Screening proteins may be very useful for distinguishing early-stage ovarian cancer with MS. Kong et al analyzed protein profiles in 3 sets of sera. The first set of patients included 21 patients with ovarian cancer, 18 patients with benign ovarian disease, and 20 normal patients.30 The second set included 32 patients with ovarian cancer, 30 patients with benign ovarian disease, and 30 age-matched healthy control patients. Third set included samples collected before and after chemotherapy from 18 patients with ovarian cancer. Sera were kept at room temperature for 1 to 3 hours for clotting before being centrifuged at 1000 rpm and again at 12000 rpm at 4°C. Then samples were immediately aliquoted and stored at −70°C. All sera were allowed to thaw once only. Afterward a detailed process was carried out to reach the final ready-to-use sample. A reasonable level of separation was reached between the cancer samples and the noncancer samples by selecting 7 peaks from patients in the first and second data set by using MS.30 Those 7 peaks were then evaluated using the third data set by comparing cancer and noncancer patients and cancer patients before and after surgery. After selecting the third data set by using MS, 6 of 7 distinct peaks that may potentially be useful in the detection and monitoring of ovarian cancer were discovered.30

In a 5-center, case–control study of hundreds of patients who were diagnosed with early-stage ovarian cancer, 3 putative markers were identified by using high-resolution MS.29 In a follow-up study of Fung et al, an attempt was made to use these posttranslational modified proteins for the classification of cancer types.31 In another study, which compared low- and high-resolution platforms, as expected, the high-resolution platform yielded superior classification patterns in patients with ovarian cancer.32

Utilizing MS to identify biomarkers was also the aim in the study of Su et al33 They tried to determine the efficacy of the 3 ovarian cancer biomarkers, namely, apolipoprotein A-I (apoA-I), transthyretin (TTR), and transferin (TF), for the detection of early-stage ovarian cancer, in direct comparison to CA125. The levels of CA125, apoA-I, TTR, and TF were measured in 392 serum samples. The serum sample was collected from 82 normal (N) patients, 24 patients with benign, 85 with low malignant potential (LMP), 126 with early-stage of cancer (ESOC), and 75 with late stage of cancer (LSOC). Their data attested to the clear improvement (over CA125) of the new panel of biomarkers for the early detection of ovarian cancer. The data also suggested that apoA-I, TTR, and TF, when analyzed collectively, were unique to ovarian cancer by MS. As a result the sensitivity of biomarkers collectively are N versus LMP 73%, N vs ESOC 84%, and N vs LSOC 97%, respectively.33

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which is one of the causes of infertility, affects 5% to 10% of females of reproductive age. Ma et al studied proteomics by using spectroscopy to understand cellular and molecular mechanisms, information on proteins, and their expression in PCOS. The complexity in the regulation of ovarian protein expression in human PCOS, they suggest this may provide a better understanding of the pathogenetic mechanisms underlying this clinical disorder.34 Their study examined the protein expression patterns in PCOS and normal ovaries and demonstrated that 69 proteins were up- or downregulated in PCOS ovaries. They identified numerous proteins that are differentially expressed in normal and PCOS ovaries and may be involved in the regulation of various biologic functions by mass spectroscopy. Discovery of distinct protein profiles for PCOS with and without insulin resistance (IR) by MS was the aim of a study by Zhao et al. The PCOS is a disease that has a long-term negative effect on the life span of a woman. Finding potential biomarkers may help physicians minimize the negative effects of PCOS. Zhao et al evaluated the serum protein peak of patients with PCOS with IR (n = 30), without IR (n = 30), and control group (n = 30). Serum samples were thawed in an ice bath and centrifuged at 8000g/min for 2 minutes at 4°C. Repeated centrifugation took place with the addition of supernatant at various times. After reading the samples, they found 8 proteins in PCOS with IR and 6 proteins without IR. These proteins are not a gold standard but may help distinguish the disease. Multiple protein peaks were observed. Therefore, the researchers suggested that in PCOS multiple biomarkers may be seen rather than a single biomarker. On the other hand, Zhao’s data also suggested that specific protein (M/Z 6629d) is associated (sensitivity and specificity are higher than 50%) with the occurrence of PCOS stronger than other proteins that have been analyzed.35 The results (sensitivity and specificity) for M/Z 6629d protein may be good for a pilot study, but it is not in the clinically usable range yet. A classical proteomics approach via the usage of mass spectrometry was done in which proteins were identified by its expression profile and peptide sequencing.36,37

Brosens et al used spectroscopy in infertile patients to evaluate the endometrium receptivity. They analyzed the proteomic of the endometrium from fertile and infertile patients. They tried to correlate apoA-I in embryo implantation failure by MS. By using this technology, they demonstrated that pelvic endometriosis increases apoA-I expression in secretory endometrium and perturbs its regulation by hCG. The abnormal level of apoA-I expression affects the endometrium receptivity.19

Proteomic analysis with MS enabled the identification of new cervical cancer biomarkers by examining the differential expression of protein in plasma specimens from different tumors. The approach was to use plasma and serum specimens for searching cervical cancer biomarkers in hopes of presenting an additional approach to Pap smear, which has a lower compliance screening and follow-up. Plasma samples were obtained from cervical squamous cell carcinoma (n = 6) and control group (n = 6; benign gynecological disease). The albumin and immunoglobulin G-depleted plasma samples were mixed with 4 volumes of precooled acetone (−20°C, 15 minutes) and incubated for 2 hours at −20°C for protein precipitation. The protein pellets were obtained after high-speed centrifugation (13 000g for 10 minutes, at 4°C), and then air-dried for 5 to 10 minutes at room temperature. The pellets were stored at −80°C until analysis. There were some proteins in plasma found by using MS that was used together with the 2-dimension electrophoresis. These proteins could be potential biomarkers (ceruloplasmin, complement C3, afamin, and alpha-1-b-glycoprotein) related to squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix and hence help in the diagnosis of the disease.20

A study, in which, samples were collected from patients with in situ cervical cancer (CIS), early invasive cervical cancer without lymph node metastasis (squamous cell carcinoma [SCC]), and control group. They utilized MS and found 6 protein peaks that could identify 84 of the 92 patients with cancer (CIS and SCC). Protein peaks also identified 36 of the 37 control cases as well. The sensitivity and specificity of this method are 91% and 97%, respectively. Two protein peaks were able to classify 55 of the 60 SCC and 31 of the 32 CIS samples, with 92% sensitivity and 97% specificity. This study demonstrates the feasibility of differentiating in situ and invasive cervical cancers through plasma protein profiling. Identification of the proteins different in invasive and in situ cancer may be important in the understanding of cervical cancer invasion and in the development of novel therapeutic intervention.21

A comparative study, done by Yang et al, of malignant and normal endometrial tissues yielded a panel of proteins displaying differential expression in malignant tissues. A prominent putative marker was identified in malignant tissues as chaperonin 10 by MS and confirmed by Western blot and immunohistochemistry. This may let to screen, to monitor, and to detect recurrent endometrial cancer disease.38

From the above studies it is clear that MS can have many different applications since it provides an increase in sensitivity. On the other hand, its optimum usage method and application area needs to be refined to reach more standard methodology. It may useful to identify multiple plasma protein markers that might be characteristic of in situ and invasive cervical cancers.20

sec.title: Fluorescence Spectroscopy
sec.p: Fluorescence spectroscopy is an emission spectroscopy technique that measures the amount of light of a certain wavelength that a substance reflects. Fluorescence spectroscopy (FS) is based on the electronic excitation induced in susceptible fluorophore molecules, such as nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH), collagen, and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), upon exposure to certain wavelengths of UV and visible light. As electrons return to their native state, light of longer wavelength than the incident light is emitted. Characteristic excitation/emission matrices illustrate the different wavelengths at which various fluorophores maximally absorb and emit light. Molecules that absorb the incident light and do not fluoresce, such as hemoglobin, also affect the spectral profile. The fluorescence emissions from a given tissue are a function of its metabolic as well as structural features, such as the neovascularization, decrease in collagen cross-linking, and biochemical changes associated with neoplasia. With FS, a real-time and noninvasive diagnosis is possible, which can quantitatively detect changes in cellular chemistry and tissue morphology.2

The FS is being studied as one of many optical technologies that make a diagnosis in real time. All the research and industrial groups studying this device in the cervix have used 2 approaches: (a) point probes that interrogate specific cervical sites, sampling 2 to 3 mm2, and (b) multispectral imaging approach that image the entire cervix. Point probe studies can biopsy the site under the probe, yielding both a “per site” and “per patient” sensitivity and specificity. Multispectral approaches suffer the requirement to register spectroscopic measurements with thickness (mm) of cervical epithelium. A formal review of the literature has yielded reports of the performance of fluorescence, reflectance, and combined spectroscopy for the in vivo screening and diagnosis of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), squamous intraepithelial lesion (SIL), and cervical neoplasia. The review focused on many of the aspects of pilot study, phase 1, phase 2, phase 3, and clinical trial design in order to examine whether these factors are important in the performance of these devices, as studied to date. A total of 26 studies were covered (2 screening and 24 diagnostic studies). These studies used 6 different device applications. Since all these devices are being compared to the current standard-of-care colposcopy, it is somewhat disconcerting that all 3 groups also report different performances of their comparison colposcopy data. The subject of the variation in colposcopy deserves further evaluation in light of these new technologies. According to the review, performance of all devices decreased when the sample size and the heterogeneity of population increased and also when the age of patients were over 50 years.39 The review presents successful findings of several studies that used different methods and spectroscopic devices.

The Pap smear has been reported to have a false negative rate of 15⁁ to 40%.40 The review presents successful findings of several studies that used different methods and spectroscopic devices. Weingandt et al designed a study to potentially find a tool for screening and diagnosing, which has more accuracy than Pap smear. To assess the feasibility of FS in the diagnosis of CIN, broadband light excitation was utilized. Collagen fibers are the main source of autofluorescence. Neoplastic transformation is associated with epithelium or increased cellular density. Epithelial neoplasm may decrease autofluorescence. By using these properties of autofluorescence, spectral measurements were taken from 685 cervical sites (in 68 patients) for the localization and differentiation of CIN and compared with colposcopically directed biopsy and HPV DNA testing. These spectral measurements were performed by imaging a 2 mm diameter tissue area through the endoscope optics via a beam splitter onto a 400 µm core quartz fiber connected to a spectrometer. Sensitivity of the equipment was tested on a fluorescence standard prior to each measurement series. A resection loop attached to the endoscope was used to achieve a predefined distance for reproducible spectral measurements. High-grade CIN lesions (CIN 2/3) presented a significantly reduced autofluorescence compared with CIN 1 (sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value for the detection of high-grade CIN (CIN 2/3) of 88%, 53%, 29%, and 95% and for CIN 3 only of 100%, 51%, 28%, and 100% were obtained, respectively). Patients with a positive HPV DNA testing showed a significantly lower autofluorescence than patients tested negative for HPV DNA. This technique demonstrated a high sensitivity for high-grade CIN of over 90%.41

In clinical practice, the preoperative discrimination between malignant and benign ovarian tumors is important, and several techniques have been described for this purpose. Visualization of ovarian tumors is possible with ultrasonography but prediction of malignancy is not accurate. Other tools, such as CT examination and MR imaging, can also not differentiate accurately between benign and malignant tumors. The FS were used to distinguish ovarian cancers from normal ovarian structures and benign neoplasms, as well as differentiate between normal variations and abnormal structures from 11 patients undergoing oophorectomy. Brewer et al explored whether FS signatures differed between normal variations within the ovary, benign neoplasms, and ovarian cancer.42 Their findings showed decreased fluorescence by neoplastic samples. The great variability in the structural changes measured and evaluated in the ovarian surface and subsurface provided valuable information for developing spectroscopy both to screen and to evaluate women for occult neoplasms.42

The FS has been used the least among all spectroscopic techniques. Its results are promising especially for screening cervical tissue and early diagnosis of pre-cancerous cervical lesions. Today, portable devices that can replace and/or complement Pap smear has been designed and put into medical usage. A medical device company in Massachusetts has recently completed clinical trials with its noncontact imaging instrument, with the intent of securing US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval for use as an adjunct to colposcopy.2

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In the field of obstetrics and gynecology, different spectroscopic techniques have been used because they are noninvasive, sensitive, specific, inexpensive, less time consuming, and examine cells in their natural state compared to traditional methods. Comparison of the spectroscopic techniques that are reviewed above is provided in Table 2.

The varying approaches to specimen preparation for different spectroscopic techniques are another important issue. Study design plays a crucial role on how to handle specimens. Some sample preparation techniques are extremely detailed, while others are more concise. At best, we tried to provide a comprehensive look. In some techniques such as mass spectroscopy, specimen has to be prepared prior to evaluation. In other techniques such as fluoresce spectroscopy, surface contact is adequate for the evaluation. Hence, usually no prior preparation is needed. Overall, whatever technique is used the common ground is to preserve the specimen without ruining it.

It is very difficult to rank or prefer one technique to the other as each technique has a different application with only a few intersecting usages. Hence, the method of usage differs from one spectroscopic technique to the other like in one technique to touch the outer tissue is enough (FS), while in another measures in vivo (NMRS). Each technique has its pros and cons (Tables 1 and 3). This situation also makes it hard to optimize or create a common ground. May be later research can at least create a more uniformed decision on which is the best technique to use for different applications.

caption.p: Advantages and Disadvantages of Spectroscopic Techniques.

list-item.p: Nondestructive examining of biological tissues 4
Minimal user training required4
Insensitive and unselective in comparison to MS 4
Requires maintenance 4
Sensitivity and selectivity are not as high as MS
Water absorbs IR very strongly making aqueous samples challenging
Noninvasive methods2,8
Can analyze many types of materials without sample preparation 4
Minimal user training required 4
Instrumental cost and complexity are reduced
Low NIR, absorbance is advantageous in many respects as many different types of materials may be analyzed without sample preparation
Same advantage of FTIR(is a high-throughput capable of measuring 1000s of spectra on a single day)
Absorptions are weaker in magnitude than FTIR2,4
The overtone and combination bands tend to be very broad and overlapping relative to the sharp, well-separated fundamental features found in the IR region
Analytically sensitive
Limited sample preparation 4
Expensive
Requires maintenance
Require highly trained personnel to execute experiments 4
Time consuming (Sometimes takes hours just for 1 tissue sample evaluation because of defining the difference between molecular ionic fragments)
No sample preparation required
Minimal user training
Compact, portable and inexpensive 4
Water provides only weak Raman signals which can disturb results
Insensitive as a result of rare Raman scattering
Requires thorough chemical knowledge to interpret spectral result
To achieve more accurate results, it has to be combined with FTIRS
Non invasive 24
Can be used to determine chemical structure of molecules and to study tissue biochemistry 24
Capable of extracting chemical information of complex mixtures
Expensive
Low throughput of samples
Required highly trained personnel 4
Time costly → ranging from less than a minute to a few hours per measurement
Limitations → cost, reproducibility and practicality (large equipment, complex peration scheme)

fn.p: Abbreviations: FTIRS, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy; NIRS, near-infrared diffuse reflectance spectroscopy; MRS, magnetic resonance spectroscopy; MS, mass spectroscopy.

sec.p: Spectroscopic techniques have been utilized in many obstetrics cases to find the mechanisms of disease and to find a way to predict disease. Using spectroscopy as a new technique, researchers identify pregnancy-related problems, such as hypertension, preeclampsia, eclempsia, and observe properties of placenta and IUGR fetus. Even the results are preliminary and are very valuable to understand the details and different aspects of disease.

Different spectroscopic techniques also have been used by researchers to identify different cancer biomarkers to provide more detailed cancer screenings like adjunct usage to Pap screening in cervix cancer. In addition, functional studies can provide additional information on the role of protein biomarker in the development and progression of cervical cancer. Ultimately, spectroscopic techniques can become integrated into the management of patients with cancer through the design and tracking of individualized therapy. Identification of the proteins different in invasive and in situ cancer may be of great value in the understanding of cervical cancer invasion and in the development of novel therapeutic intervention in the future.

In infertility, the techniques have been applied to select the most suitable embryo for transfer. They can also be utilized in further studies for analysis of stem cell differentiation in human embryos. They might enable us to distinguish human embryonic stem cells, which have own spectroscopic measure result. Researchers are focused to find different protein biomarkers and other molecular levels’ peak in gynecologic diseases like premature ovarian failure and early prediction of premenopause. Also studies may provide important insights for a better understanding of the molecular mechanism underlying clinical manifestations of diseases and the identification of causative molecular factors and the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

There are still many shortcomings that have to be overcome. This review shows that there are many different techniques in spectroscopy and each have their own advantages and disadvantages. For the time being, the best option for different applications is not clear. Standardization is still an issue to be resolved. Further studies likely will help guide new engineering and clinical applications of spectroscopic techniques, optimizing the best method for different applications in the field of obstetrics and gynecology.
